Set aside this analogy:

Dharma Wisdom said:
Buddha's disciple!
The merit treasury of the bodhisattva who has first given rise to the mind, a hundred times, a thousand times, up to countless times, cannot be compared to even a fraction of it.
Why is it so?
Buddha's disciple!

All buddhas, when first generating the mind of enlightenment, do not appear in the world for the sake of providing all objects of enjoyment to sentient beings in ten asaá¹ƒkhyeya worlds in the ten directions, for a hundred eons, up to a thousand koá¹­Ä«s of nayutas of eons;

Nor do they appear in the world for the sake of teaching sentient beings to cultivate the five precepts, the ten wholesome [deeds], the four meditations, the four immeasurable [minds], the four formless concentrations, the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, the fruit of arhatship, and the path of pratyekabuddhahood;
In order to not cut off the lineage of buddhas, they generate the mind of enlightenment;
In order to fill all worlds in the ten directions, they generate the mind of enlightenment;

In order to completely liberate all sentient beings, they generate the mind of enlightenment;ğŸ”½In order to completely know the formation and destruction of all worlds, they generate the mind of enlightenment;
In order to completely know the arising of the defilements and purity of sentient beings in all worlds, they generate the mind of enlightenment;
To completely understand the pure nature of all worlds, one arouses the mind of enlightenment;
To completely understand the false afflictions and habitual tendencies of all beings, one arouses the mind of enlightenment;

To completely understand the death of all beings and their rebirth in other places, one arouses the mind of enlightenment;ğŸ”½To completely understand the faculties and skillful means of all beings, one arouses the mind of enlightenment;
To completely understand the thoughts in the minds of all beings, one arouses the mind of enlightenment;
To completely discern all beings in the three times, one arouses the mind of enlightenment;
To completely understand the equal realm of all Buddhas, one arouses the mind of enlightenment.
Buddha's disciple!
Let us set aside this analogy:

Suppose there is a person who can, in a single thought, pass through the immeasurable worlds in the east. With this kind of spiritual power, that person travels east for immeasurable, countless asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of eons, yet still cannot reach the limit of the worlds in the east;

Furthermore, a second person, with spiritual powers and freedom, in a single thought can surpass the worlds traversed by the first person in incalculably long eons, yet even if this second person were to travel eastward for incalculably long eons, he still would not reach the limit of the worlds;
Furthermore, a third person, with spiritual powers and freedom, in a single thought can surpass the worlds traversed by the first person in incalculably long eons;
Furthermore, a fourth person, with spiritual powers and freedom, in a single thought can surpass the worlds traversed by the first person in incalculably long eons;
Furthermore, a fifth person, with spiritual powers and freedom, in a single thought can surpass the worlds traversed by the first person in incalculably long eons;
Furthermore, a sixth person, with spiritual powers and freedom, in a single thought can surpass the worlds traversed by the first person in incalculably long eons;
Moreover, the seventh person, with his spiritual powers and freedom, can in a single thought surpass the worlds traversed by the person before him in incalculably long eons;

Moreover, the tenth person, with his spiritual powers and freedom, can in a single thought surpass the worlds traversed by the person before him in incalculably long eons;

That tenth person, with his most supreme and free spiritual powers, would travel east from here for incalculably long eons, yet still would not reach the end of the worlds, and the same would be true in the ten directions;

In this way, it continues to a hundred people. The most excellent and sovereign spiritual power of that person, in immeasurable, innumerable, incalculable eons, reaches the ten directions, and one can still understand and reach the limit of it. The treasury of merits of the bodhisattva who has first given rise to the mind cannot be known. Why is it so?
The bodhisattva who has first given rise to the mind does not set a limit, giving rise to the bodhi mind for the sake of the sentient beings of so many worlds;
It is for the sake of all sentient beings in the ten directions and all worlds, in order to deliver all sentient beings, in order to discern all worlds, that one gives rise to the bodhi mind;
In order to know that the subtle world is precisely the great world, and to know that the great world is precisely the subtle world;
To know that the small world is precisely the many worlds, and to know that the many worlds are precisely the small world;
To know that the vast world is precisely the narrow world, and to know that the narrow world is precisely the vast world;
Knowing that one world is precisely immeasurable and boundless worlds, knowing that immeasurable and boundless worlds are precisely one world;
Knowing that immeasurable and boundless worlds enter one world, knowing that one world enters immeasurable and boundless worlds;
Knowing that a defiled world is precisely a pure world, knowing that a pure world is precisely a defiled world;
In a single pore, completely discerning and knowing all worlds, in all worlds, completely discerning and knowing the nature of a single pore;

Knowing that a single world gives rise to all worlds, knowing that all worlds are like empty space, wishing to know all worlds in a single thought, without exception, therefore giving rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Buddha's disciple!
Set aside this analogy:

Suppose there were a person who, in the eastern direction, in worlds beyond measure, beyond number, and beyond calculation, in a single thought could discern the number of their formation and destruction. If this person diligently applied this method, thought after thought in succession, for immeasurable, incalculable, and incalculable eons, he still would not be able to know the number of the formation and destruction of worlds in the eastern direction;

Moreover, a second person, in a single thought, could fully understand the number of worlds that had formed and been destroyed in the immeasurable, incalculable, and incalculable eons of the first person. If this person diligently applied this method, thought after thought in succession, for immeasurable, boundless, and incalculable eons, he still would not be able to fully know the number of the formation and destruction of worlds in the eastern direction;
In this way, it would continue in this manner up to the tenth person;

The tenth person, in a single thought, can fully understand the number of world systems that have been formed and destroyed over an incalculably long period of time, as calculated by the ninth person. Even if this person diligently applied this method, moment by moment, for incalculably long periods of time, he still would not be able to fully understand the number of world systems that have been formed and destroyed in the eastern direction, and the same is true for the other nine directions.
The number of world systems that have been formed and destroyed in the ten directions can still be fully understood;
The treasury of merits of a bodhisattva who has first given rise to the mind of enlightenment cannot be known. Why is this?
A bodhisattva-mahÄsattva does not give rise to the mind of enlightenment in order to know the number of world systems and the number of eons of formation and destruction in a limited way;

In order to know that a long eon is precisely a short eon, and a short eon is precisely a long eon;

Knowing that in different kalpas there are no different kalpas, and knowing that in no different kalpas there are different kalpas;
Knowing that kalpas with an end are kalpas without an end, and knowing that kalpas without an end are kalpas with an end;
Knowing that innumerable kalpas are one thought, and knowing that one thought is innumerable kalpas;
Knowing that all kalpas enter into no kalpas, and knowing that no kalpas enter into all kalpas;

In order to completely understand the past, future, and present limits, as well as the formation and destruction of all worlds in the kalpas, one gives rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
This is called the bodhisattva's first great vow adornment, namely:
The illumination of wisdom that completely understands all kalpas.

The minds of all sentient beings can all be distinguished and known,
All the dust motes in the worlds can still be counted their number.
The space element in the ten directions can still be measured with a single hair,
The initial giving rise to the bodhi mind by bodhisattvas is ultimately immeasurable.
Because of the initial bodhi mind, the Buddhas of the three times are born,
And all sentient beings enjoy various kinds of supreme bliss.
The merits praised by the Buddha are all fully possessed because of this,
Within the Buddha's realm, their minds are free from doubt.
If one can forever part from all doubts and uncertainties,
Then one can extinguish the immeasurable obstructions of sentient beings.
Because of the initial mind of enlightenment, one purifies the lands of the Buddhas,
Causing all beings to be replete with subtle wisdom.
If one wishes to see the lands of the ten directions, the Buddhas of the three times,
And also to attain the immeasurable, profound treasury of merits and virtues,
If one wishes to extinguish the immeasurable suffering of birth and death of sentient beings,
One should establish firm vows
